title: network drop caused DB corruption (same SHA-1 prefix) and reindex lost hundreds of packages
body:
As per the issue title above, a network drop while I was working on `regcm` package caused a DB corruption, which showed the following error:
```
==> Error: Specs
libtool@2.4.6%intel@18.0.3 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64  ^libsigsegv@2.11%gcc@8.2.0 cflags="-O2" cxxflags="-O2" fflags="-O2"  arch=linux-centos7-x86_64  ^m4@1.4.18%gcc@8.2.0 cflags="-O2" cxxflags="-O2" fflags="-O2"  patches=3877ab548f88597ab2327a2230ee048d2d07ace1062efe81fc92e91b7f39cd00,c0a408fbffb7255fcc75e26bd8edab116fc81d216bfd18b473668b7739a4158e,fc9b61654a3ba1a8d6cd78ce087e7c96366c290bc8d2c299f09828d793b853c8 +sigsegv arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
and
libtool@2.4.6%intel@18.0.3 cflags="-O2" cxxflags="-O2" fflags="-O2"  arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
have the same SHA-1 prefix!
```
I then tried a `spack reindex`, but it didn't work, and moreover, it now doesn't see hundreds of packages I've installed in spack, which are still installed and available at `opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/`.
```
# tree -L 2 opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/ |wc -l
290
```

while:
```
# spack find
==> 15 installed packages
-- linux-centos7-x86_64 / gcc@7.2.0 -----------------------------
darshan-util@3.1.6

-- linux-centos7-x86_64 / gcc@8.2.0 -----------------------------
gdbm@1.14.1  libsigsegv@2.11  m4@1.4.18  ncurses@6.1  perl@5.26.2  readline@7.0  zlib@1.2.11

-- linux-centos7-x86_64 / intel@18.0.3 --------------------------
libpciaccess@0.13.5  libtool@2.4.6  libxml2@2.9.8  pkgconf@1.5.4  util-macros@1.19.1  xz@5.2.4  zlib@1.2.11
```

I tried also removing the db locks:
```console
# rm var/spack/stage/.lock opt/spack/.spack-db/prefix_lock opt/spack/.spack-db/lock
```
and renaming the index:
```console
# mv opt/spack/.spack-db/index.json{,.bkp}
```
but it didn't help, even after another `spack reindex`.

### Information on the system

 1. CentOS 7.5, working on https://github.com/exactlab/spack/tree/regcm_fixes, which I rebased this morning to upstream develop 8f0fc259
 2. some compilers installed, gcc@{4.8.5,7.2.0,8.2.0}, pgi, intel@18

I'm a bit worried: is there a way to perform a "full reindex" or force a reindex on `opt/`?
